metadata.titleEn: EPMA data of chlorite from Jingchong co Cu polymetallic deposit, Hunan Province
metadata.description:
This data is EPMA data of chlorite from Jingchong co Cu polymetallic deposit in Hunan Province. The experimental method is EPMA. The test was completed in the Key Laboratory of nonferrous metal metallogenic prediction, Ministry of education, Central South University. The analytical instrument is Shimadzu epma-1720 electron probe equipped with four channel spectrometer and energy spectrometer. The experimental conditions are: accelerating voltage 20 kV, beam current 15 Na, beam spot diameter 1 μ m. ZAF correction method. The standard samples used for EPMA analysis of chlorite are apatite (P), rutile (TI), jadeite (al, Na), almandine (FE), rosapyroxene (MN), olivine (mg), diopside (CA, SI) and potash feldspar (k). This data can provide data support for future geochemical model analysis of Jingchong co Cu polymetallic deposit in Hunan Province.
The above data have been published in EI high-level journals, and the data are true and reliable. The data is stored in Excel.
metadata.instructions: The EPMA data are stored in Excel format. "Chl Ⅰ (zjc-6)" in the excel header represents the chlorite generation and sample number respectively. The data point number format is "q1-07", where a-cc is the number and Q is the constant.

literatureList.titleEn: Mineralogical characteristics and mineralization significance of chlorite, pyrite, and chalcopyrite in the Jingchong cobalt-copper polymetallic deposit in Hunan.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to obtain EPMA data for chlorite minerals in a polymetallic deposit?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to obtain EPMA data for chlorite minerals in a polymetallic deposit involves using an SHIMADZU EPMA-1720 electron probe micro-analyzer equipped with a four-channel spectrometer and an energy spectrometer. The experiment is conducted under conditions of 20 kV accelerating voltage, 15 nA beam current, and a 1 μm beam diameter, employing the ZAF correction method for accuracy. Standard samples like apatite (P), rutile (Ti), jadeite (Al, Na), almandine (Fe), rhodonite (Mn), olivine (Mg), diopside (Ca, Si), and orthoclase (K) are used for calibration.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features and conditions of the EPMA data collection method used for analyzing chlorite in polymetallic deposits?
Feature Specification.Answer: SHIMADZU EPMA-1720, four-channel spectrometer, energy dispersive spectrometer, accelerating voltage of 20 kV, beam current of 15 nA, beam diameter of 1 μm, ZAF correction method, standard samples: apatite (P), rutile (Ti), jadeite (Al, Na), almandine (Fe), rhodonite (Mn), olivine (Mg), diopside (Ca, Si), orthoclase (K)

Quantification.Question: What is the beam current used in the EPMA data collection method for analyzing chlorite in the cobalt-copper polymetallic deposit?

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting EPMA data for chlorite in the context of polymetallic deposits in Hunan, and how does it contribute to the development of geochemical models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of collecting EPMA data for chlorite in the context of polymetallic deposits in Hunan is to provide reliable and precise geochemical information that can support the development of geochemical models for the Jin Chong cobalt-copper polymetallic deposit. This data aids in understanding the mineralogical composition and geochemical characteristics of the deposit, which is crucial for predicting mineralization processes and enhancing mineral exploration strategies.

Enablement.Question: What experimental conditions and technological setups enable the accurate collection of EPMA data on chlorite in multi-metallic ore deposits?
Enablement.Answer: The accurate collection of EPMA data on chlorite in multi-metallic ore deposits is enabled by using a SHIMADZU EPMA-1720 electron probe microanalyzer equipped with a four-channel spectrometer and energy spectrometer. The experimental conditions include an accelerating voltage of 20 kV, beam current of 15 nA, and a beam spot diameter of 1 μm, along with the ZAF correction method. Standard samples like apatite (P), rutile (Ti), jadeite (Al, Na), almandine (Fe), rhodonite (Mn), olivine (Mg), diopside (Ca, Si), and orthoclase (K) are used for calibration.
